results.title: Artificial insemination of cattle
results.creator_credit: Tom Stobart and Dartington Hall Film Unit
results.brief_description: This film illustrates, by means of actual scenes and animated diagrams, the process of the artificial insemination of cattle, stresses the importance of the practice to stockbreeders and shows just how a centre for this purpose is set up and run.

results.title: Artificial insemination
results.brief_description: Produced for the Royal Agricultural Society of NSW, regarding the attempts to pursue dairy and cattle grazing, and to examine and use artificial insemination as a means of improving stock.

results.title: Article 55
results.creator_credit: Leo Seltzer and Department of Public Information of the United Nations
results.brief_description: Article 55 of the United Nations Charter provides for the promotion of economic and social progress and development. The film shows how a mission to Bolivia was established, and pictures the complete problem which faces them. Shows also how Bolivia suffers with other undeveloped countries the burdens of ill health, of relying on depression prone primary exports, and of lacking the fundamental facilities which attract overseas capital.

results.title: Art survives the times
results.brief_description: A record of art life in France. Leading artists such as Matisse, Picasso, Ultrillo and the sculptors, Roualt, Laurens and Janniot, are shown at work. The architects, Le Corbusier and Perret, also display plans for homes and cities. No other credits available.

results.title: Art from found materials
results.brief_description: Many artists use ‘found materials’ with imagination. They use such natural things as seeds and shells as well as scrap materials. Both collage and assemblage are illustrated. The materials used, their organisation, and techniques for adhering offer endless possibilities for creative form and images. No other credits available.

results.title: Art by Bruce Petty
results.brief_description: Cartoonist Bruce Petty turns his acid wit and frenetic graphics to the subject of art. A montage of images questions the nature of art appreciation and the relationship between art and life. Filmed in the Indianapolis Museum of Art.
results.description: Cartoonist Bruce Petty turns his acid wit and frenetic graphics to the subject of art. A montage of images questions the nature of art appreciation and the relationship between art and life. Filmed in the Indianapolis Museum of Art.

results.title: Art and perception: learning to see
results.brief_description: The viewer is encouraged to look for the visual elements of art- colour, line, texture and form- as the film explores different settings: the country, the city and the seashore. Presents a variety of paintings of these environments that illustrate the visual inspiration and imaginative inventiveness the artist brought to his subject. No other credits available.

results.title: Art and life in Belgium (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Charles Dekeukeleire, Henri Kerels and PDK Pictures
results.brief_description: The countryside of Flanders, Brabant and Wallonia in Belgium has for centuries attracted artists who have interpreted the changing seasons and depicted various types of inhabitants of the regions. This film shows how these sources of inspiration have remained unchanged. Comparisons of the work of artists of different periods with the landscape and types of inhabitants to be seen in Flanders and the surrounding districts today. Artists whose work is illustrated include P. Breughel, Rubens and Van Eyck.

results.title: Falling cats
results.creator_credit: Andrew Horne, Deborah Szapiro and Lilyfield Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Great moments in science: presented by Dr Karl Kruszelnicki”.
It is safer for a cat to fall from a thirty-two story building than a seven story building and testing these things are easy in the ready made environment of New York and its high rise. It is said that one hundred and thirty two cats in five months fall from high rise buildings. Lots of information has been gathered, and it had been found that ninety percent of cats survive. In fact, the higher the building, the higher the chance of survival, the shorter the distance, the greater the chance of broken bones. Find out more in this animation, it is very interesting.

results.title: Arrow up yours
results.creator_credit: Andrew Horne, Deborah Szapiro, Freerange Aninmation and Karl Kruszelnicki
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Great moments in science: presented by Dr Karl Kruszelnicki”.
This entertaining animation presented by Karl Kruszelnicki explains the bow and arrow and its history and in so doing provides an explanation for the well known two finger salute. There is mention of the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, and how the well trained British used the Welsh long bow to attack the French. All this adds up to the reason behind the two finger salute.
